output.conclusion: This course provides an advanced understanding of IC Engines, equipping students with the knowledge to analyze, design, and optimize engine performance for various applications.
output.introduction: Welcome to Advanced IC Engines! This course delves into the intricate details of internal combustion engines, covering advanced thermodynamics, combustion phenomena, engine design, and modern control strategies. It is designed for students and professionals with a foundational understanding of IC engine principles.

chapters.description: Review of ideal cycles (Otto, Diesel, Dual) and their limitations. Introduction to real engine cycles and deviations from ideal behavior.
Accounting for variable specific heats, dissociation, and chemical equilibrium in air-standard cycle analysis. Effects on cycle efficiency and performance.
Applying exergy analysis to identify and quantify irreversibilities in IC engines. Strategies for minimizing exergy destruction and improving efficiency.
Detailed analysis of combustion stoichiometry, including air-fuel ratio, equivalence ratio, and exhaust gas composition. Introduction to chemical kinetics and reaction mechanisms.
Understanding the fundamentals of laminar and turbulent flame propagation in premixed and non-premixed mixtures. Factors affecting flame speed and stability.
Overview of different combustion modeling approaches, including zero-dimensional, multi-zone, and computational fluid dynamics (CFD) models.

chapters.chapterTitle: Engine Design Parameters and Performance Metrics
chapters.description: Detailed discussion of engine design parameters (bore, stroke, compression ratio) and their impact on engine performance metrics (power, torque, efficiency).
Principles of intake and exhaust system design for optimizing volumetric efficiency and reducing pumping losses. Wave action and tuning effects.
Techniques for balancing reciprocating engines to minimize vibration and noise. Analysis of engine vibration modes and frequencies.

chapters.chapterTitle: Fuel Injection Systems: Gasoline and Diesel
chapters.description: Detailed analysis of gasoline and diesel fuel injection systems, including injector design, spray characteristics, and injection timing strategies.
Overview of alternative fuels (biofuels, hydrogen, natural gas) and their impact on engine performance and emissions. Advanced combustion strategies (HCCI, RCCI).
Principles of engine lubrication and cooling systems for maintaining engine durability and preventing overheating. Oil pump design and coolant flow management.
Introduction to engine control strategies for optimizing engine performance, fuel economy, and emissions. Feedback control algorithms and sensor integration.
Overview of engine management systems (EMS) architecture, components, and functions. Calibration and tuning of EMS parameters.
Techniques for diagnosing engine problems and detecting faults using diagnostic codes and sensor data. Troubleshooting procedures and repair strategies.
